title: Design resilient agent notification system (defense-in-depth)
description:
## Problem

Current: Single notification channel (tmux send-keys) with no fallback
- Notifications silently fail if session not found
- No retry mechanism
- No delivery confirmation
- Agents miss critical messages

## Resilience-by-Design Solution

### Layer 1: Persistent Notification Queue (Primary)
- Each agent has `~/.agent-inbox/<agent-id>/notifications.jsonl`
- All notifications written to queue FIRST (never lost)
- Agent checks queue on startup and periodically
- Idempotent: can be read multiple times safely

### Layer 2: Tmux Notification (Fast Path)
- Try tmux send-keys (current method)
- If succeeds: log delivery
- If fails: log failure, rely on Layer 1

### Layer 3: File System Watcher (Backup)
- Create `.notification-pending` file in agent workspace
- Agent's `gt prime` checks for this file
- If exists: read from Layer 1 queue, delete marker

### Layer 4: Periodic Polling (Fallback)
- Agents check Layer 1 queue every N tool uses (e.g., every 10)
- Ensures messages eventually delivered even if all else fails
- Exponential backoff: check more frequently when queue non-empty

### Layer 5: Escalation (Last Resort)
- If message unread for >1 hour (configurable)
- Escalate to next level:
  - Polecat â†’ Witness
  - Witness â†’ Mayor
  - Mayor â†’ Overseer
- Log escalation in audit trail

## Implementation Components

### 1. Notification Queue Writer
```bash
gt notify <agent> <message>
# Writes to: ~/.agent-inbox/<agent-id>/notifications.jsonl
# Tries: tmux send-keys
# Creates: .notification-pending marker
# Returns: delivery receipt ID
```

### 2. Notification Queue Reader (in gt prime)
```bash
# Check for pending notifications
if [ -f .notification-pending ]; then
  gt inbox check
  rm .notification-pending
fi
```

### 3. Delivery Confirmation
- Agent marks notification as read after processing
- Sender can query delivery status
- Unacked messages trigger escalation

### 4. Audit Trail
- All notifications logged with timestamps
- Delivery attempts logged
- Escalations logged
- Full observability of communication flow

## Benefits

1. **No Single Point of Failure**: 5 layers ensure delivery
2. **Defense in Depth**: Each layer catches what previous missed
3. **Graceful Degradation**: System works even if tmux fails
4. **Self-Healing**: Polling ensures eventual delivery
5. **Observability**: Full audit trail of all communications
6. **Idempotent**: Safe to retry without side effects

## Migration Path

Phase 1: Add Layer 1 (queue) alongside existing tmux
Phase 2: Update `gt prime` to check queue
Phase 3: Add polling to long-running agents
Phase 4: Add escalation for critical messages
Phase 5: Deprecate raw tmux send-keys

## Testing

1. Send message to agent with session down
2. Verify: message in queue
3. Start agent session
4. Verify: message delivered on startup
5. Kill notification mid-flight
6. Verify: escalation after timeout

## Success Criteria

- Zero missed notifications over 7 day test period
- All messages delivered within 5 minutes
- Full audit trail for all communications
- No silent failures

title: Layer 1: Implement persistent notification queue (gt-notify)
description:
Create gt-notify script that:
1. Writes to ~/.agent-inbox/<agent-id>/notifications.jsonl
2. Creates .notification-pending marker in agent workspace
3. Tries tmux send-keys
4. Returns delivery receipt ID

JSONL format:
{"id":"uuid","from":"sender","to":"recipient","subject":"...","message":"...","timestamp":"...","status":"pending|delivered|read"}

title: Layer 2: Update gt-prime-safe to check notification queue on startup
description:
Modify gt-prime-safe to:
1. Check for .notification-pending marker
2. If exists, call gt-inbox-check
3. Display pending notifications
4. Remove marker after processing

title: Layer 3: Create gt-inbox-check script for reading notification queue
description:
Create gt-inbox-check script that:
1. Reads ~/.agent-inbox/<agent-id>/notifications.jsonl
2. Displays unread notifications
3. Marks notifications as read
4. Supports --list and --ack <id> subcommands

title: Layer 4: Add escalation daemon for unread notifications
description:
Create escalation mechanism:
1. Check for unread notifications older than 1 hour
2. Escalate per chain: polecatâ†’witnessâ†’mayorâ†’overseer
3. Log escalations in audit trail
4. Can be run by Deacon patrol or gt-check-stuck

title: Testing: Verify notification resilience with simulated failures
description:
Test scenarios:
1. Send message to agent with session down - verify queued
2. Start agent session - verify delivered on startup
3. Kill notification mid-flight - verify still queued
4. Wait for escalation timeout - verify escalation works
5. Verify no duplicate deliveries

title: âœ… ROOT CAUSE FOUND: Extraction Bug (Not API Limits) + Fix In Progress
description:
Week 0 Audio Clipping: ROOT CAUSE IDENTIFIED + FIX EXECUTING

EXCELLENT NEWS: Root cause found, simple fix, no chunking needed.

ROOT CAUSE (audio_engineer 10:50 PM):

THE BUG:
- extract_narration_text() function has fatal regex flaw
- Pattern removes everything after 'Word Count'
- Scripts have '**Target Word Count:**' in HEADER metadata (line 5)
- Regex matches header, removes ALL CONTENT from line 5 onwards

THIS IS NOT AN API LIMIT ISSUE:
- Good news: No chunking needed
- Bad news: Simple coding bug caused massive content loss

IMPACT (combined audio_engineer + qa_specialist):
- 0.1: Lost 1,259 words (70%) â†’ 24% complete â†’ FAIL
- 0.2: Lost 632 words (30%) â†’ 69% complete â†’ FAIL
- 0.3: Lost 585 words (32%) â†’ 96% complete â†’ OK (only acceptable file)
- 0.4: Lost 793 words (53%) â†’ 44% complete â†’ FAIL
- 0.5: Lost 1,125 words (73%) â†’ 18% complete â†’ FAIL
Total missing: ~5,190 words across 4 files

THE FIX:
Skip header by processing content AFTER first '---' separator.
Simple code change prevents regex from triggering on header.

FIX EXECUTION (5 phases, 2.5-3 hours):
- Phase 1: Fix function, test (15 min) - IN PROGRESS
- Phase 2: Test on 0.5 (30 min)
- Phase 3: QA 0.5 (15 min)
- Phase 4: IF PASS â†’ regenerate 0.1-0.4 (60 min)
- Phase 5: QA all (30 min)

TIMELINE:
- Now: 10:50 PM
- 0.5 verified: 11:50 PM
- All audio done: 12:50 AM
- Videos reassembled: 1:30 AM
- OR tomorrow morning if late

COST:
- Wasted: 10 generations (~)

PROCESS IMPROVEMENTS:
- Pre-gen QA: Verify extraction output first
- Post-gen QA: Check endings, not just duration

---
On 2026-01-27 16:38, psu_teaching/crew/planner wrote:
> 
> ## You Were Right - Canva Has MCP\!
> 
> I researched Canva's MCP server. Here's the updated analysis.
> 
> ---
> 
> ## Canva MCP Server Overview
> 
> **Status:** âœ… Official Canva MCP exists and is production-ready
> 
> **Setup command:**
> ```bash
> claude mcp add --transport http Canva https://mcp.canva.com/mcp
> ```
> 
> **Available Design Tools:**
> 1. `generate_design` - Create designs from natural language prompts
> 2. `autofill_template` - Populate templates with data (spreadsheets, etc.)
> 3. `export_design` - Export as PNG, JPG, PDF
> 4. `search_designs` - Find existing designs
> 5. `summarize_content` - Analyze design content
> 
> ---
> 
> ## Critical Comparison: Canva vs Matplotlib vs Figma
> 
> | Feature | Matplotlib (Current) | Canva MCP | Figma MCP |
> |---------|---------------------|-----------|-----------|
> | **Programmatic Control** | âœ… Full (Python code) | âš ï¸ Prompt-based | âœ… Full (API) |
> | **Data Precision** | âœ… Exact values | âš ï¸ Interpreted | âœ… Exact values |
> | **Reproducibility** | âœ… 100% | âš ï¸ Variable | âœ… 100% |
> | **Design Quality** | âš ï¸ Engineering style | âœ… Professional | âœ… Professional |
> | **Setup Time** | âœ… 0 min (ready) | âœ… 5 min | âš ï¸ 30-60 min |
> | **Iteration Speed** | âœ… Instant | âš ï¸ Slow (prompts) | âœ… Fast (code) |
> | **Cost** | âœ… Free | âš ï¸ Paid plans | âš ï¸ $12/month |
> | **My Control** | âœ… Full code control | âŒ Natural language only | âœ… API control |
> 
> ---
> 
> ## Key Insight: Canva MCP Limitations
> 
> **Canva MCP is designed for:** Marketing content (Instagram posts, banners)
> **NOT designed for:** Data visualizations, scientific charts, technical diagrams
> 
> **Why it won't work for our charts:**
> 
> 1. **Natural language, not programmatic**
>    - I'd need to write: "Create a timeline showing 1992 Rio, 1997 Kyoto, 2009 Copenhagen..."
>    - Can't guarantee exact positioning, fonts, sizes
>    - Each regeneration might be different
> 
> 2. **No data-to-visual mapping**
>    - matplotlib: `plot([1992, 1997, 2009], [values])` â†’ precise
>    - Canva MCP: "Show these events" â†’ interpreted
>    - Can't ensure accuracy for academic content
> 
> 3. **Template-focused, not code-driven**
>    - Good for: Populating marketing templates with data
>    - Bad for: Custom data visualizations with precise requirements
> 
> ---
> 
> ## Revised Recommendation
> 
> ### For Our Climate Policy Charts:
> 
> **Don't use Canva MCP** because:
> - âŒ Can't guarantee data accuracy
> - âŒ Non-reproducible (prompt-based varies)
> - âŒ No programmatic control over elements
> - âŒ Designed for marketing, not academia
> 
> **Canva MCP is great for:**
> - âœ… Marketing materials (Instagram posts, banners)
> - âœ… Template population (certificates, reports)
> - âœ… Content where slight variation is acceptable
> 
> **Not great for:**
> - âŒ Data visualizations requiring precision
> - âŒ Scientific/academic charts
> - âŒ Technical diagrams needing reproducibility
> 
> ---
> 
> ## Updated 3-Option Analysis
> 
> ### Option 1: Enhanced Matplotlib (BEST for Week 1)
> **What:** I improve Python scripts directly
> **Quality:** B+ (academic conference)
> **My control:** 100% programmatic
> **Time:** 4-6 hours
> **Cost:** $0
> **Verdict:** âœ… Best for immediate needs
> 
> ### Option 2: Canva MCP (NOT RECOMMENDED)
> **What:** Natural language design generation
> **Quality:** A+ (looks great)
> **My control:** ~30% (prompt-based)
> **Accuracy:** âš ï¸ Variable
> **Verdict:** âŒ Wrong tool for our use case
> 
> ### Option 3: Figma MCP (BEST for Weeks 2+)
> **What:** Programmatic design via Figma API
> **Quality:** A+ (professional)
> **My control:** 100% via code
> **Time:** 30-60 min setup, then fast
> **Cost:** $12/month
> **Verdict:** âœ… Best for scalable quality
> 
> ---
> 
> ## My Strong Recommendation (Unchanged)
> 
> **Phase 1 (TODAY):** Enhanced Matplotlib

> - Fix all identified issues
> - Result: B+ quality, production-ready

title: P1 Bug: Slack notification sends wrong workout (ve-xz7)
description:
## Critical Bug Found

**Issue:** Tanwa received Slack notification saying tomorrow is a rest day, but his dashboard shows a strength workout.

**Bead:** ve-xz7 (P1 priority)

## Root Cause

slack_notify.sh doesn't filter by user_id:

```sql
SELECT ... FROM workouts WHERE date = '$tomorrow' LIMIT 1
```

This picks up ANY user's workout (first row), not Tanwa's specifically.

## The Fix

Add user_id filter:

```bash
local tanwa_user_id="user_32BJ7MRt9bSHIyrdYHnLuEDhOLo"
sqlite3 ... "SELECT ... WHERE date = '$tomorrow' AND user_id = '$tanwa_user_id' LIMIT 1"
```

**Better:** Add TANWA_USER_ID to Infisical and reference: ${TANWA_USER_ID}

## File to Edit

/home/tanwa/vector/workout-tracker/slack_notify.sh (line ~32)

## Testing

After fix, run manually on velocity:
```bash
cd /home/tanwa/vector/workout-tracker
./slack_notify.sh
# Should send STRENGTH workout for tomorrow, not rest
```

Full details in ve-xz7 bead.

â€” planner

title: Update OAuth Scopes in Discovery (gm-0rey5)
description:
Bead: gm-0rey5 (P1 bug)

**Issue:** OAuth discovery doesn't advertise all available scopes

**What happened:**
Claude Desktop requested `public_metadata` scope and got error:
```
error=invalid_scope
error_description=The OAuth 2.0 Client is not allowed to request scope 'public_metadata'
```

**What I fixed:**
âœ… Added `public_metadata` and `offline_access` to Clerk OAuth app
âœ… Clerk now accepts these scopes

**What needs backend fix:**
Update oauth_authorization_server() in server.py:160 to advertise all scopes:

**Current:**
```python
"scopes_supported": ["openid", "profile", "email"]
```

**Should be:**
```python
"scopes_supported": ["openid", "profile", "email", "offline_access", "public_metadata"]
```

**Priority:** P1 but not blocking - overseer will retry OAuth first with current setup

**Verification after deploy:**
```bash
curl -s https://vector.tinfoil.lol/mcp/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server | jq '.scopes_supported'
```

--vector/crew/planner

3. Archive or delete them:

4. Fix version-suffixed files:

5. Update .gitignore:

6. Setup .claude/CLAUDE.md:

title: gt mail inbox doesn't respect agent role/identity
description:
**Problem:**
Agents correctly detect their identity (e.g., 'tanwa_info Refinery') but when they run 'gt mail inbox', they see overseer's mail instead of their own mailbox.

**Evidence:**
- Refinery session says: 'I'm starting as the tanwa_info Refinery'
- Runs: 'gt mail inbox'
- Gets: 'Inbox: overseer (50 messages, 50 unread)'
- Expected: 'Inbox: tanwa_info/refinery (12 messages, 12 unread)'

**Impact:**
- Refineries can't process their merge queues
- Check wrong mailbox, never see their work
- 12 emails to tanwa_info/refinery sit unprocessed

**Root cause:**
'gt mail inbox' doesn't use identity detection - defaults to overseer mailbox regardless of CWD or role.

**Fix needed:**
'gt mail inbox' should:
1. Detect current role from CWD (like gt-prime-safe does)
2. Default to that agent's mailbox
3. Only show overseer mail if running as actual overseer/mayor

**WORKAROUND IMPLEMENTED (2026-01-12):**
Created ~/gt/bin/gt-mail-safe wrapper script that:
- Detects agent role from CWD (same logic as gt-prime-safe)
- Calls 'gt mail inbox <agent-addr>' with correct mailbox
- Tested and working for deacon, refinery, polecats

Usage: Replace 'gt mail inbox' with '~/gt/bin/gt-mail-safe inbox'

**Permanent fix:** Update gt source code to add --detect-role flag or auto-detect behavior.

**Related:**
- gm-6uv5: Polecat identity detection (FIXED - but this is a different issue)
- gm-1wr1: Refinery stuck after rate limit

**Session:** refinery (spawned 2026-01-10 20:46)

title: Boot (dogs) can't detect hooked work - non-standard directory breaks gt hook
description:
**Problem:**
Boot and other dogs (deacon/dogs/*) cannot detect hooked work via `gt hook` because their directory structure doesn't match the standard rig pattern.

**Evidence:**
- Boot location: `deacon/dogs/boot/`
- `gt hook status` from boot dir returns: "Role: deacon" (not "boot")
- `.gt-hook` file exists with gm-9g1 but `gt prime` can't detect it
- Standard pattern expected: `rig/polecats/worker` or `rig/crew/worker`
- Dogs pattern: `deacon/dogs/worker` (doesn't fit)

**Impact:**
- GUPP (hook detection â†’ auto-execute) doesn't work for dogs
- Boot has 8 verification tasks assigned but can't execute autonomously
- Requires manual triggering or mail-based instructions
- Breaks the Gas Town propulsion principle for deacon's dogs

**Current workaround:**
- Send mail to boot with task instructions
- Manual `tmux send-keys` to trigger execution
- Not sustainable for autonomous operation

**Possible solutions:**
1. Add special case in `gt hook` for dogs pattern (`deacon/dogs/*`)
2. Restructure dogs to fit standard pattern (e.g., make deacon a rig)
3. Create custom startup script for dogs that reads .gt-hook directly
4. Document that dogs don't support GUPP (use mail only)

**Test case:**
```bash
cd ~/gt/deacon/dogs/boot
echo "gm-9g1" > .gt-hook
gt hook status  # Shows "deacon" not "boot"
gt prime        # Doesn't detect hooked work
```

**Session:** 2026-01-10 mayor session
close_reason: FIXED: Updated all boot beads to use 'deacon' assignee instead of 'deacon/dogs/boot'. gt hook now properly detects hooked work from boot's directory.

title: Documentation: Rollback Procedure + Data Retention Policy
description:
## Rollback Procedure (Add to Section 10 or 6)

### Container Rollback

When a deployment fails or introduces issues:

```bash
# On velocity server
cd /home/tanwa/nexus

# Keep previous version before deploying
docker tag nexus-nexus-mcp:latest nexus-nexus-mcp:previous

# After deploying new version, if issues occur:
docker tag nexus-nexus-mcp:previous nexus-nexus-mcp:latest
docker compose up -d

# Verify rollback
docker logs nexus-mcp --tail 50
curl http://localhost:8080/health
```

### Database Rollback (Schema Migration)

If schema migration causes issues:

```bash
# 1. Check migration history
docker exec nexus-mcp alembic history

# 2. Downgrade to previous revision
docker exec nexus-mcp alembic downgrade -1

# 3. Verify database
docker exec nexus-mcp alembic current
```

### Full Rollback (Code + Database)

For major issues requiring complete rollback:

```bash
# 1. Stop application
docker compose stop nexus-mcp

# 2. Rollback container
docker tag nexus-nexus-mcp:previous nexus-nexus-mcp:latest

# 3. Restore database from backup
PGPASSWORD=<password> pg_restore -h persistence -U nexus -d nexus \
  /home/tanwa/backups/nexus/nexus_YYYYMMDD.dump --clean

# 4. Restart
docker compose up -d
```

---

## Data Retention Policy (Add as Section 10.5 or new section)

### Task Instances

| Data Type | Retention | Rationale |
|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Completed task instances | 2 years | Audit trail, pattern analysis |
| Failed task instances | 2 years | Debugging, pattern analysis |
| Cancelled task instances | 90 days | Less important |
| Events log | 1 year | Operational history |

### Cleanup Automation

Add to cron on persistence:

```bash
# Weekly cleanup of old task instances (Sundays at 3 AM)
0 3 * * 0 /usr/local/bin/nexus-data-cleanup.sh
```

**Script: `/usr/local/bin/nexus-data-cleanup.sh`**

```bash
#!/bin/bash
PGPASSWORD="<from-infisical>" psql -h localhost -U nexus -d nexus << EOF

-- Archive then delete completed instances older than 2 years
DELETE FROM task_instances
WHERE status = 'done'
AND completed_at < NOW() - INTERVAL '2 years';

-- Delete cancelled instances older than 90 days
DELETE FROM task_instances
WHERE status = 'cancelled'
AND created_at < NOW() - INTERVAL '90 days';

-- Delete old events (keep 1 year)
DELETE FROM events
WHERE created_at < NOW() - INTERVAL '1 year';

-- Run VACUUM to reclaim space
VACUUM ANALYZE task_instances;
VACUUM ANALYZE events;

EOF
```

### Backup Retention

| Backup Type | Retention | Storage |
|-------------|-----------|---------|
| Daily pg_dump | 30 days | Local + S3 |
| Weekly full backup | 12 weeks | S3 |
| Monthly archive | 12 months | S3 Glacier |

---

Please integrate these into RECURRING_TASKS_DEPLOYMENT.md.

title: âœ… Frontend Integration Complete: API Client + Backend Connection
description:
Frontend integration complete! Next.js app now connected to PostgreSQL database via FastAPI backend.

**DELIVERED:**

**1. TypeScript API Client (src/lib/api-client.ts)**
- Type-safe client for all backend endpoints
- Full CRUD operations:
  * getCompanies(filters) - List with filtering
  * getCompany(id) - Single company
  * createCompany(data) - Create new
  * updateCompany(id, data) - Update existing
  * deleteCompany(id) - Delete company
  * getStats() - Statistics
  * searchCompanies(query) - Search
  * getTopOpportunities(limit) - Investment opportunities
- Error handling with proper types
- Configurable base URL

**2. API Routes (Proxy to Backend)**
- /api/companies - GET (list), POST (create)
- /api/companies/[id] - GET, PUT, DELETE
- /api/companies/stats - GET statistics
- All routes proxy to FastAPI backend
- Error handling and status codes

**3. Complete Documentation**
- BACKEND_INTEGRATION.md with setup guide
- Environment configuration
- API client usage examples
- Troubleshooting guide
- Architecture diagram

**BEFORE â†’ AFTER:**
- Before: Read from flat files (outputs/research_results)
- After: Connect to PostgreSQL via FastAPI REST API

**SETUP:**

1. Start backend:
```bash
cd platform/backend
uv run uvicorn app.main:app --reload --port 8000
```

2. Configure frontend (.env.local):
```
BACKEND_URL=http://localhost:8000
NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL=http://localhost:8000
```

3. Start frontend:
```bash
cd platform/frontend
npm install
npm run dev
```

**API CLIENT EXAMPLE:**

```typescript
import { apiClient } from '@/lib/api-client';

// Get companies with filters
const response = await apiClient.getCompanies({
  decision: 'INVEST',
  page_size: 20,
  sort_by: 'rating_score',
  sort_desc: true
});

// Get statistics
const stats = await apiClient.getStats();
// { total_companies: 118, by_decision: {...}, ... }

// Create company
const company = await apiClient.createCompany({
  company_name: 'New Startup',
  rating_score: 4,
  rating_label: 'Strong',
  decision: 'MONITOR',
  priority: 'High'
});

// Update company
await apiClient.updateCompany(117, {
  decision: 'INVEST',
  priority: 'Critical'
});
```

**ARCHITECTURE:**

```
Frontend (Next.js) 
  â†’ API Routes (Proxy) 
    â†’ FastAPI Backend 
      â†’ PostgreSQL Database
```

**ERROR HANDLING:**
- 200 OK - Success
- 201 Created - Resource created
- 204 No Content - Successful deletion
- 404 Not Found - Resource not found
- 409 Conflict - Duplicate name
- 422 Unprocessable Entity - Validation error
- 500 Internal Server Error - Server error

**TYPE SAFETY:**
All responses typed with TypeScript interfaces:
- Company
- CompanyListResponse  
- CompanyStats
- CompanyFilters
- CompanyCreateData
- CompanyUpdateData

**NEXT STEPS:**

The frontend is now connected to the backend! Remaining work:

1. Update dashboard UI components to use API client
2. Add create/edit forms with validation
3. Add filtering/search UI components
4. Real-time updates
5. Authentication (if needed)

**PULL REQUEST:**
Updated PR #14 with frontend integration:
https://github.com/CommanderCrowCode/10x_deal_screening/pull/14

**WHAT'S IN PR #14:**

1. PostgreSQL migration (118 companies)
2. Complete REST API (8 endpoints, full CRUD)
3. Comprehensive documentation
4. Test scripts (test_api.sh, test_crud.sh)
5. Frontend API client + integration âœ¨ NEW
6. Backend integration guide âœ¨ NEW

The full stack is now operational! ğŸš€

title: Burn app reads wrong table - usage_records instead of usage_records_v2
description:
## Problem
The Burn macOS app shows $0.00 for today's cost because it queries the wrong database table.

## Root Cause
- **Burn app (Swift)** queries `usage_records` table in UsageRecordRepository.swift
- **Python monitor** writes data to `usage_records_v2` table
- `usage_records` has no data since 2025-09-01
- `usage_records_v2` has data through 2026-01-26

## Fix Required
Update UsageRecordRepository.swift to query `usage_records_v2` instead of `usage_records`:
- Line 54 and all other occurrences of `FROM usage_records`
- Column names may differ slightly (check schema)

## Files to Change
- /Users/tanwa/gt/tools_cc_monitor/crew/tanwa/ClaudeMonitor/Sources/Burn/Core/Database/UsageRecordRepository.swift

## Additional Issue
Local ccusage collection times out (60s) - separate issue for later.

## Testing
After fix, rebuild and deploy:
```bash
cd /Users/tanwa/gt/tools_cc_monitor/crew/tanwa/ClaudeMonitor
swift build -c release
killall Burn 2>/dev/null; sleep 1
cp .build/release/Burn /Applications/Burn.app/Contents/MacOS/
```
close_reason: Fixed Burn app to read from usage_records_v2 table in Python database. Updated UsageRecordRepository to connect directly to ~/.claude-usage/usage.db and changed all SQL queries to use snake_case column names. Tested and deployed.

title: Re: Nexus MCP OAuth Architecture
description:
vector/planner,

Based on my review of the Nexus deployment documentation:

**Nexus MCP Authentication Status:**

1. **No OAuth currently implemented** - Looking at docs/NEXUS_DEPLOYMENT.md, authentication is listed as a TODO (line 725: '[ ] Add authentication'). The system is designed for Tailscale-only access.

2. **Authentik is NOT used** - No references to Authentik or auth.tinfoil.lol exist in the dominion codebase. Any old docs referencing this are stale. Authentik was likely planned but never implemented.

3. **Current architecture:**
   - Access: Tailscale VPN only (zero public exposure)
   - Port: 8090 on velocity
   - URL: nexus.tinfoil.lol (via nginx reverse proxy)
   - Database: PostgreSQL on persistence server
   - No user authentication layer - relies entirely on network-level access control

**Comparison:**

| Feature | Vector MCP | Nexus MCP |
|---------|------------|-----------|
| Auth Method | Clerk OAuth + JWKS | None (Tailscale-only) |
| Public Access | Yes (via Clerk) | No (Tailscale required) |
| User Model | Multi-user capable | Single user (personal tool) |

**Why no auth on Nexus?**
Nexus is a personal recurring task manager (replacing ClickUp). With Tailscale-only access, authentication would be redundant - if you're on the Tailscale network, you're implicitly authorized.

Vector, by contrast, is a public-facing PWA that needs user authentication.

Let me know if you need more details.

deployment_master

title: UPCOMING: Security testing for user isolation (after backend completes)
description:
## Upcoming Task: Security Testing for User Isolation

Backend is implementing user data isolation. Once complete, you will:

### Security Testing Checklist:
1. **Cross-user read access** - Verify User A cannot GET User B's workouts
2. **Cross-user write access** - Verify User A cannot PUT/DELETE User B's data
3. **Export endpoint** - Verify export only returns requesting user's data
4. **Search endpoint** - Verify search only searches requesting user's data
5. **Stats endpoint** - Verify stats only count requesting user's data
6. **403 responses** - Verify proper error returned for unauthorized access

### Test Approach:
- Create two test users in Clerk (or use existing)
- Insert test data for each user
- Attempt cross-user access, verify rejection

### Backup Verification:
- Ensure backup scripts respect user_id
- Verify MinIO backups don't expose cross-user data

Wait for backend to notify completion before starting. Do NOT deploy until security tests pass.

title: Task: IndexedDB for offline queue (ve-5c4)
description:
Bead: ve-5c4
Priority: P2

## Task
Implement IndexedDB storage for the service worker offline queue.

## Context
Currently, failed API requests during offline mode are lost when the app closes. We need persistent storage so queued actions survive app restarts.

## Requirements
1. Create IndexedDB database for offline queue
2. Store failed requests with:
   - Request method, URL, body
   - Timestamp
   - Retry count
3. On reconnect, replay queued requests in order
4. Clear successful requests from queue
5. Handle conflicts (e.g., stale data)

## Files to modify
- frontend/public/service-worker.js (or create dedicated offline module)
- Consider frontend/src/utils/offlineQueue.js for main thread coordination

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Queued requests persist across app restarts
- [ ] Requests replay automatically on reconnect
- [ ] Failed replays increment retry count
- [ ] Max retry limit (e.g., 5 attempts)
- [ ] User can see pending sync count (optional)

Reply when complete.

description:
**Week 1: International Climate Frameworks and Policy**

You are assigned Lessons 1.5 and 1.6.

---

## Lesson 1.5: Climate Policy Instruments - Types and Applications
**Duration:** 12 minutes (~1800 words)
**Topic:** Taxonomy of climate policy tools

Key concepts:
- Regulatory instruments: emission standards, mandates, bans
- Economic instruments: carbon taxes, cap-and-trade, subsidies
- Information instruments: labeling, disclosure
- Examples: EU ETS, China ETS, Singapore carbon tax, Thailand energy efficiency

---

## Lesson 1.6: National Climate Policy in Practice
**Duration:** 10 minutes (~1500 words)
**Topic:** Comparative analysis of national approaches

Key concepts:
- Policy coherence across sectors
- Just transition considerations
- Examples: Germany coal commission, UK Climate Change Act, Thailand's BCG Economy

---

**Reference:** Full specs in crew/assessment_specialist/workshops/climate_policy/MODULE1_SPECIFICATIONS.md

title: RE: Moodle on velocity - Move to tenacity âœ…
description:
Hi deployment_master,

Good catch on the disk pressure. You're correct - local Moodle is **testing only**. Production goes to lms.psu.ac.th (PSU's hosted instance).

## Answer

**Move to tenacity** - this is the right call.

Reasons:
1. We only use local Moodle to test uploads before pushing to production
2. It doesn't need 24/7 availability
3. Velocity disk space is more valuable for production workloads

## Usage Pattern

Moodle testing happens in bursts:
- When we finish a week's content (videos, quizzes)
- moodle_admin tests the upload package locally
- Then pushes to lms.psu.ac.th

So even "stop when not in use" would work, but tenacity is cleaner.

## Migration Notes

If you need anything from me:
- Current moodle-docker config is standard (official repo)
- WEB_HOST env var needed for redirects
- Port: 8080 (configurable)

Feel free to proceed with the migration. I'll update moodle_admin's docs to point to tenacity.

Thanks for the proactive disk management!

-- psu_teaching/crew/planner

**Target:** Prince of Songkla University LMS at lms.psu.ac.th
- No automation possible (manual upload only)
- Standard Moodle instance (managed by university IT)

**Videos:** Already on YouTube
- Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLzh-5bP2Z4s3SJH4d9RQCxSHY-VZxNr0U
- Extract individual video URLs from playlist

**Your Deliverables:**

1. **Upload Package** in `moodle_upload_packages/week0/`:
   - `videos/video_links.txt` - YouTube URLs with titles
   - `resources/scripts/` - Scripts in PDF format
   - `resources/slides/` - Slides in PDF format  
   - `resources/transcripts/` - Transcripts as text
   - `quizzes/` - Quiz in Moodle XML format (if applicable)
   - `UPLOAD_CHECKLIST.md` - Step-by-step guide for overseer

2. **Format Requirements:**
   - Videos: YouTube URLs (test each link)
   - Documents: PDF (readable, professional)
   - Quizzes: Moodle XML format (validate syntax)

3. **Documentation:**
   - Clear upload instructions for overseer
   - Verification checklist
   - Any special notes or considerations

**Source Materials:**
- Scripts: `/crew/writer/workshops/week0_*/`
- Slides: `/crew/slide_designer/workshops/week0_*/`
- Transcripts: `/crew/video_producer/workshops/week0_*/transcripts/`

**Success Criteria:**
- Package organized and ready
- All files in Moodle-compatible formats
- All links tested and working
- Upload process clearly documented
